[[File:Black lung screening.jpg|thumb|right|A Radiographer explains an x-ray to a coal miner participating in screening. Patient education can include explaining the results of diagnostic tests.]] '''Patient education''' is the process by which [[health professional]]s and others impart information to patients and their caregivers that will alter their health behaviors or improve their health status.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://odphp.osophs.dhhs.gov/pubs/GUIDECPS/text/iv_edu.txt|title=iv. Patient Education and Counseling for Prevention|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421064558/http://odphp.osophs.dhhs.gov/pubs/GUIDECPS/text/iv_edu.txt|archivedate=April 21, 2014|deadurl=y}}</ref>
==Overview== Education may be provided by any healthcare professional who has undertaken appropriate training education, education on patient communication and education is usually included in the healthcare professional's training.
[[Health education]] is also a tool used by [[managed care]] plans, and may include both general [[Preventive medicine|preventive]] education or [[health promotion]] and disease or condition specific education.<ref>Peter R. Koongstvedt, "The Managed Health Care Handbook," Fourth Edition, Aspen Publishers, Inc., 2001, page 788 {{ISBN|0-8342-1726-0}}</ref>
Important elements of patient education are skill building and responsibility: patients need to know when, how, and why they need to make a lifestyle change. Group effort is equally important: each member of the patient’s health care team needs to be involved.It can also help the patients by a better lifestyle, it give them the ability to learn new information.
The value of patient education can be summarized as follows: *Improved understanding of medical condition, diagnosis, disease, or disability. *Improved understanding of methods and means to manage multiple aspects of medical condition. *Improved self-advocacy in deciding to act both independently from medical providers and in interdependence with them. *Increased Compliance – Effective communication and patient education increases patient motivation to comply. *Patient Outcomes – Patients more likely to respond well to their treatment plan – fewer complications. *Informed Consent – Patients feel you've provided the information they need. *Utilization – More effective use of medical services – fewer unnecessary phone calls and visits. *Satisfaction and referrals – Patients more likely to stay with your practice and refer other patients.<ref>[http://www.krames.com Krames Patient Education]</ref> *Risk Management – Lower risk of malpractice when patients have realistic expectations.<ref>[http://www.patient-education.com/?p=editorial&s=xplainresearch&ver=~2 Patient Education Institute, Research evidence]</ref>
The competencies of a [[health educator]] include the following:<ref>{{cite book|last=Bastable|first=Susan B.|title=Health Professionals as Educator|year=2011|publisher=Jones & Barlett Learning, LLC|location=Sudbury, MA|pages=6}}</ref> *Incorporate a personal ethic in regards to social responsibilities and services towards others. *Provide accurate, competent, and evidence-based care. *Practice preventative health care. *Focus on relationship-centered care with individuals and their families. *Incorporate the multiple determinants of health when providing care. *Be culturally sensitive and be open to a diverse society. *Use technology appropriately and effectively. *Be current in the field and continue to advance education. There are many areas where patient education can improve the outcomes of treatment. * For example, in patients with amputations, patient education has been shown to be effective when approached from all angles by the healthcare team (nurse, primary care physician, prosthetist, physical therapist, occupational therapist etc.). Support groups have been shown to be a helpful method for dealing with depression in this population. Preoperative patient education helped patients with their decision making process by informing them of factors related to pain, limb loss, and functional restriction faced after amputation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pantera|first=E.|last2=Pourtier-Piotte|first2=C.|last3=Bensoussan|first3=L.|last4=Coudeyre|first4=E.|title=Patient education after amputation: Systematic review and experts’ opinions|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1877065714000165|journal=Annals of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine|volume=57|issue=3|pages=143–158|doi=10.1016/j.rehab.2014.02.001}}</ref> * In the case of arthritis, patient education was found to be administered through three methods, including individual face to face meetings with healthcare professionals, patient groups, online support programs. Category I evidence was found for individual, face to face counseling. Meeting with rheumatologists, occupational therapists, physical therapists, nurses, and other healthcare providers was found to be effective in creating adherence to treatment, medication, and for improving overall patient health.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zangi|first=Heidi A.|last2=Ndosi|first2=Mwidimi|last3=Adams|first3=Jo|last4=Andersen|first4=Lena|last5=Bode|first5=Christina|last6=Boström|first6=Carina|last7=Eijk-Hustings|first7=Yvonne van|last8=Gossec|first8=Laure|last9=Korandová|first9=Jana|date=2015-06-01|title=EULAR recommendations for patient education for people with inflammatory arthritis|url=http://ard.bmj.com/content/74/6/954|journal=Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases|language=en|volume=74|issue=6|pages=954–962|doi=10.1136/annrheumdis-2014-206807|issn=1468-2060|pmid=25735643}}</ref> * In the case of [[rheumatoid arthritis]], patient education has been shown as an effective non-pharmacological treatment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brosseau|first=Lucie|last2=Rahman|first2=Prinon|last3=Poitras|first3=Stéphane|last4=Toupin-April|first4=Karine|last5=Paterson|first5=Gail|last6=Smith|first6=Christine|last7=King|first7=Judy|last8=Casimiro|first8=Lynn|last9=Angelis|first9=Gino De|title=A Systematic Critical Appraisal of Non-Pharmacological Management of Rheumatoid Arthritis with Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation II|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0095369|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=9|issue=5|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0095369|pmc=4026323|pmid=24840205}}</ref>

The theme of '''poet as legislator''' reached its [[Grandiosity|grandiose]] peak in the [[Romanticism|Romantic era]],<ref>C. Prendergast ed., ''Cultural Materialism'' (1995) p. 222</ref> epitomised in the view of the lonely, alienated poet as 'unacknowledged legislator' to the whole world.<ref>Richard Holmes, ''Dr Johnson and Mr Savage'' (1994) p. 51</ref>
However the concept had a long prehistory in Western culture, with classical figures like [[Orpheus]] or [[Solon]] being appealed to as precedents for the poet's civilising role.<ref>D. Griffin, ''Patriotism and Poetry in Eighteenth-Century Britain'' (2005) p. 70</ref>
==Classical origins==
[[Plato]]'s opposition to poets in his ideal Republic was predicated on the contemporary existence of [[Homer]]ic expounders who claimed that "a man ought to regulate the tenour of his whole life by this poet's directions".<ref>J. L. Davies/D. J. Vaughan trans., ''The Republic of Plato'' (1908) p. 352</ref> Plato only allowed the already censured poet to guide the young, to be an acknowledged legislator at the price of total external control.<ref>E. B. Castle, ''Ancient Education and Today'' (1969) p. 91</ref>
Less threatened by the poetic role, the Romans by contrast saw poetry, with [[Horace]], as primarily pleasing, and only secondarily as instructive.<ref>M. H. Abrams, ''The Mirror and the Lamp'' (1971) p. 16</ref>
==Renaissance and Augustan views==
Building the view of the fifteenth century Florentine [[Neoplatonism in the Renaissance|Neoplatonists]] on the poet as seer,<ref>M. H. Abrams, ''The Mirror and the Lamp'' (1971) p. 272</ref> however, [[Sir Philip Sidney]] developed a more powerful concept of the poet as overtopping the philosopher, historian and lawyer to stand out as "the monarch...of all sciences.<ref>J. A van Dorsten ed, ''Sidney: A Defence of Poetry'' (1984) p. 39</ref>
Such a viewpoint was more or less institutionalised in [[Augustan literature]], Johnson's [[Rasselas]] maintaining for example that the poet "must write as the interpreter of nature and the legislator of mankind"<ref>Samuel Johnson, ''Rasselas'' (1905) p. 42</ref> – a fully public, even patriotic role moreover<ref>D. Griffin, ''Patriotism and Poetry in Eighteenth-Century Britain'' (2005) p. 71-2</ref>
==Romantic peaks==
By contrast the Romantic view of the poet as ''unackowledged'' legislator emerges at the turm of the century in the writing of [[William Godwin]], with his anarchic view of the poet as "the legislator of generations and the moral instructor of the world".<ref>Quoted in J. A. Carlson, ''England's First Family of Writers'' (2007) p. 267</ref>
It received its most memorable formulation however in [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]]'s 1820 "[[A Defence of Poetry]]".<ref>I. Ousby ed., ''The Cambridge Guide to Literature in English'' (1995) p. 245</ref> Shelley maintained that, through their powers of imaginative understanding, 'Poets' (in the widest sense, of ancient Greece) were able to identify and formulate emerging socio-cultural trends; and were as a result "the hierophants of an unapprehended inspiration...the unacknowledged legislators of the world".<ref>Quoted in M. H. Abrams, ''The Mirror and the Lamp'' (1971) p. 332</ref>
==Modernist irony==
The grand claims of the Romantics began to give way in the twentieth century to a more ironic stance<ref>S. Chatterji, ''Memories of a Lost War'' (2001) p. 70</ref> – [[Yeats]] speaking for his calling in general when he wrote "We have no gift to set a statesman right".<ref>W. B. Yeats, ''The Poems'' (1984) p. 155</ref>
What remained of the Shelley claim was to be further diminished by [[Postmodernism]]'s distrust for grand narratives, if not perhaps destroyed entirely.<ref>[http://call-for-papers.sas.upenn.edu/node/33792 Tools of the Sacred]</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Bard]] * [[Christopher Hitchens]] * [[Clerisy]] * [[Mark Akenside]] * [[Matthew Arnold]] * [[Pushkin]] * [[The arts and politics]] * [[Václav Havel]] }}

{{refimprove|date=May 2018}}
In [[mathematics]], more precisely in [[formal language theory]], the profinite words are the generalization of the notion of finite words into a [[Cauchy completion|complete topological space]]. This notion allows to use [[topology]] to study languages and finite semigroups. For example, profinite words are used to give an alternative characterization to the algebraic notion of [[variety of finite semigroups]].
==Definition==
Let '''A''' an [[Alphabet (formal languages)|alphabet]]. The set of profinite words over '''A''' consists in the [[Completion (topology)|completion]] of a metric space defined on the set <math>\hat A^*</math> of words over '''A'''. The distance used to define this metric space is defined using a notion of separation of words. Those notions are now defined.
===Separation=== Let '''M''' and '''N''' [[monoid]]s, let '''p''' and '''q''' be elements of the monoid '''M'''. Let '''φ''' a [[morphism]] of monoid from '''M''' to '''N'''. It is said that the morphism φ separates '''p''' and '''q''' if <math>\phi(p)\ne\phi(q)</math>. For example, the morphism <math>\phi:A^*\to \mathbb Z/2\mathbb Z, w\mapsto |w|</math> sending a words to the parity of its length separates the words '''ababa''' and '''abaa'''. Indeed <math>\phi(ababa)=1\ne0=\phi(abaa)</math>.
It is said that '''N''' separates '''p''' and '''q''' if there exists a morphism of monoid φ from '''M''' to '''N''' which separates '''p''' and '''q'''. Using previous example, <math>\mathbb Z/2\mathbb Z</math> separates '''ababa''' and '''abaa'''. More generally, <math>\mathbb Z/n\mathbb Z</math> separates any words whose size are not congruent modulo '''n'''. In general, any two distinct words can be separated, using the monoid whose elements are the factors of '''p''' plus a fresh element 0. The morphism sends prefixes of '''p''' to themselves and everything else to 0.
===Distance=== The distance between two distinct words '''p''' and '''q''' is defined as the inverse of the size of the least morphism '''N''' separating '''p''' and '''q'''. Thus, the distance of '''ababa''' and '''abaa''' is <math>\frac12</math>. The distance of '''p''' and itself is defined as 0.
This distance '''d''' is ultrametric, and furthermore it satisfies <math>d(uw,vw)\le d(u,v)</math> and <math>d(wu,wv)\le d(u,v)</math>.
Since any word '''p''' can be separated from any other word using a monoid with '''|p|+1''' elements, where '''|p|''' is the length of '''p''', it follows that the distance between '''p''' and any other word is at least <math>\frac{1}{|p|}</math>. Thus the topology defined by this metric is discrete. ===Profinite topology=== The profinite topology over '''A''', denoted <math>\hat A^*</math>, is the [[Completion (topology)|completion]] of the set of finite words under the distance defined above. It should be noted that the completion preserve the monoid structure.
The topology <math>\hat A^*</math> is compact.
Any monoid morphism <math>\phi:A^*\to M</math>, with '''M''' finite can be extended uniquely into a morphism <math>\hat\phi:\hat A^*\to M</math>, and this morphism is uniformly continuous. Furthermore, it is the least topological space with this property.
===Profinite word=== A profinite word is an element of the profinite topology. And a profinite language is a set of profinite word. Each finite words are profinite words. A few examples of profinite words which are not finite are now given.
For '''m''' any word, let <math>m^\omega</math> denote <math>\lim_{i\to\infty}m^{i!}</math>. Note that <math>m^{i!}</math> is a [[Cauchy sequence]]. Intuitively, to separate <math>m^{i!}</math> and <math>m^{i'!}</math>, a monoid should count at least up to <math>\min(i,i')</math>, hence requires at least <math>\min(i,i')</math> elements. Since <math>m^{i!}</math> is a [[Cauchy sequence]], <math>x^\omega</math> is indeed a profinite word.
Furthermore, the word <math>x^\omega</math> is idempotent. This is due to the fact that, for any morphism <math>\phi:A^*\to N</math> with '''N''' finite, <math>\phi(m^{i!})=\phi(m)^{i!}=n^{i!}</math> for some '''n''' belonging to '''N'''. Since '''N''' is finite, for '''i''' great enough, <math>n^{i!}</math> is idempotent, and the sequence is constant.
Similarly, <math>m^{\omega+1}</math> and <math>m^{\omega-1}</math> are defined as <math>\lim_{n\to\infty}m^{n!+ 1}</math> and <math>\lim_{n\to\infty}m^{n!-1}</math> respectively.
==Profinite languages== The notion of profinite languages allow to relate notions of [[semigroup theory]] to notions of topology. More precisely, given '''P''' a profinite language, the following statements are equivalent: *'''P''' is clopen. *'''P''' is [[recognizable_set|recognizable]], *The [[syntactic congruence]] of '''P''' is clopen, as a subset of <math>\hat A^*\times\hat A^*</math>.
Similar statements also holds for languages '''P''' of finite words. The following conditions are equivalent. *<math>P</math> is recognisable (as a subset of <math>A^*</math>), *the [[closure (topology)|closure]] of '''P''', <math>\overline P</math>, is recognisable (as a subset of <math>\hat A^*</math>), where *<math>P=K\cap A^*</math>, for some clopen '''K''', *<math>\overline P</math> is clopen.
Those characterisations are due to the more general fact that, taking the closure of a finite language, and restricting a profinite language to finite words are inverse operations, when they are applied to recognisable languages.
==References== {{cite book|last1=Pin|first1=Jean-Éric|title=Mathematical Foundations of Automata Theory|date=2016-11-30|pages=130-139|url=http://www.liafa.jussieu.fr/~jep/PDF/MPRI/MPRI.pdf}} {{cite book|last1=Almeida|first1=J|title=Finite semigroups and universal algebra|date=1994|publisher=World Scientific Publishing Co. Inc.|location=River Edge, NJ|isbn=981-02-1895-8}}

'''Pseudolaw''' consists of statements, beliefs, or practices that are claimed to be based on accepted law or legal doctrine, but which deviate significantly from most conventional understandings of law and jurisprudence, or which originate from non-existent statutes or legal principals the advocate or adherent of incorrectly believes exist.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Powell|first1=Corey|title=Here comes pseudolaw, a weird little cousin of pseudoscience|url=https://aeon.co/ideas/here-comes-pseudolaw-a-weird-little-cousin-of-pseudoscience|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=[[Aeon (digital magazine)|Aeon]]|date=March 21, 2016}}</ref> It is sometimes referred to as "legalistic gibberish".<ref>{{cite web|title=T.C. Memo. 2000-11|url=https://www.ustaxcourt.gov/InOpHistoric/MARSH.TCM.WPD.pdf|website=ustaxcourt.gov|publisher=[[U.S. Tax Court]]|accessdate=January 4, 2018}}</ref> The more extreme examples have been classified as [[paper terrorism]].
Followers of such ideologies can cause problems for courts and government administrators by filing unusual applications that are difficult to process. Courts in Canada refer to such arguments as '''Organized Pseudolegal Commercial Arguments''', and have called them frivolous and vexatious.<ref>''[http://canlii.ca/en/ab/abqb/doc/2012/2012abqb571/2012abqb571.html Meads v. Meads, 2012 ABQB 571]''(CanLII), Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta, 18 September 2012, para. 77</ref> There is no recorded instance of such tactics being upheld in a court of law.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/nov/18/freeman-land-strategy-bullet-debt |title=The freeman-on-the-land strategy is no magic bullet for debt problems |last1=Bizzle |first1=Legal |date=18 November 2011 |website=The Guardian }}</ref>
Common among psudolegal beliefs is a belief that one is partially or fully sovereign from the country in which they live, and believe that no laws, or only certain laws, apply to them. Groups espousing such pseudolegal beliefs include [[freemen on the land]] and the [[sovereign citizen movement]]. Some believe that their state itself is illegitimate, such as [[Reichsbürgerbewegung]].
Also under the umbrella of pseudolegal arguments are [[conspiracy theorists]] who believe there is a secret parallel legal system that one can access through certain means, like using a secret phrase or by placing stamps on the right place on documents. For example, the [[redemption movement]] believes that a secret fund is created for everyone at birth by the government, and that a procedure exists to "redeem" or reclaim money from this fund. See [[tax protester conspiracy arguments]] for a discussion of these beliefs related to tax law. Many of these revolve around the "legal name fraud" movement, which believes that birth certificates give the state legal ownership of a [[personal name]] and refusing to use this name therefore removes oneself from a court's jurisdiction.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dalgleish|first1=Katherine|title=Guns, border guards, and the Magna Carta: the Freemen-on-the-Land are back in Alberta courts|url=https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=018e9df4-b9fe-4c88-9db9-d784f423348c|website=lexology.com|publisher=Lexology|accessdate=January 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Kelly|first1=John|title=The mystery of the 'legal name fraud' billboards|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-36499750|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=[[BBC News]]|date=June 11, 2016}}</ref> Various groups advocate that one can avoid this state ownership by distinguishing between capitalized and non-capitalized versions of one's name, or by adding punctuation to one's name. See [[strawman theory]] (also known as the capital letters argument) for more information.
==See also== * [[Pseudoscience]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Proseline|date=January 2015}} '''Rhetorical modes''' (also known as '''modes of discourse''') describe the variety, conventions, and purposes of the major kinds of [[language]]-based [[communication]], particularly [[writing]] and [[speaking]]. Four of the most common rhetorical modes and their purpose are [[Narrative mode|narration]], [[description]], [[Exposition (narrative)|exposition]], and [[Argumentation theory|argumentation]].{{sfn|Rozakis|2003|p=271}} The first codification of these rhetorical modes was by Samuel P. Newman in ''A Practical System of Rhetoric'' in 1827.{{sfn|Connors|1981|p=445}}
==Narration== {{further|Exposition (narrative)}} {{Refimprove section|date=September 2014}} The purpose of [[narrative mode|narration]] is to tell a story or narrate an event or series of events. This writing mode frequently uses the tools of descriptive writing. Narration is an especially useful tool for sequencing or putting details and information into some kind of logical order, usually chronological. Working with narration helps us see clear sequences separate from all other mental functions. Examples include: *[[Anecdote]]s *[[Autobiography]] *[[Biography]] *[[Novel]]s *[[Oral history]] *[[Short story]]
==Description== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2014}} The purpose of description is to re-create, invent, or visually present a person, place, event, or action so that the reader can picture that which is being described. Descriptive writing can be found in the other rhetorical modes. Examples include: *[[Personal journal|Journal writing]] *[[Poetry]]
==Exposition== Expository writing is a type of [[writing]] where the purpose is to explain, inform, or even describe.<ref name=ball>{{cite web|last=Ball|first=Arnetha F.|title=Expository Writing|url=http://www.stanford.edu/~arnetha/expowrite/info.html|publisher=Stanford University}}</ref> It is considered to be one of the four most common rhetorical modes.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nordquist|first=Richard|title=Expository Writing|url=http://grammar.about.com/od/e/g/Expository-Writing-term.htm|publisher=About.com}}</ref>
The purpose of expository writing is to explain and analyze information by presenting an idea, relevant evidence, and appropriate discussion. In [[narrative]] contexts (such as [[history]] and [[fiction]]), [[exposition (narrative)|exposition]] provides background information to teach or entertain. In other [[nonfiction]] contexts (such as [[technical communication]]), the purpose is to teach and inform. Examples include:{{sfn|Rozakis|2003|p=271}} * Business **[[Business letter]]s **[[Report]]s **[[News release|Press releases]] * Journalism **[[How-to|How-to essays, such as recipes and other instructions]] **[[Article (publishing)|News article]] * Personal **[[Personal letter]]s **[[Will (law)|Wills]] * Academic and [[technical communication]] **[[Scientific writing]] ***[[Scientific report]]s ***[[Scientific journal]] articles **[[Academic writing]] ***[[Term paper]]s ***[[Textbook]]s ***General [[reference work]]s ****[[Encyclopedia|Encyclopedia articles]] **[[Technical writing]] ***[[User guide]]s ***[[Technical standard]]s
==Argumentation== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2014}} The purpose of argumentation (also called ''[[persuasive writing]]'') is to prove the validity of an idea, or point of view, by presenting sound reasoning, discussion, and argument to thoroughly convince the reader. Persuasive writing/Persuasion is a type of argumentation with the additional aim to urge the reader to take some form of action. Examples include: *[[Copywriting|Advertising copy]] *[[review|Critical review]] *[[Editorial]]s *[[Job evaluation]] *[[Job application]] letter *[[Letter of recommendation]] *[[Letter to the editor|Letters to the editor]] *[[Résumé]]s
Another form of persuasive rhetoric is satirical rhetoric, or using humor in order to make a point about some aspect of life or society. Perhaps the most famous example is [[Jonathan Swift]]'s "[[A Modest Proposal]]".
==Fiction-writing modes== Each [[fiction-writing mode]] has its own purposes and conventions. Agent and author Evan Marshall identifies five fiction-writing modes: action, summary, dialogue, feelings/thoughts, and background.<ref>{{harvtxt| Marshall | 1998 | pp = 143–165}}</ref> Author and writing-instructor [[Jessica Page Morrell]] lists six delivery modes for fiction-writing: action, exposition, description, dialogue, summary, and transition.<ref>{{harvtxt | Morrell | 2006 | p = 127}}</ref> Author [[Peter Selgin]] refers to ''methods'', including action, dialogue, thoughts, summary, scene, and description.<ref>{{harvtxt | Selgin | 2007 | p = 38}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Exposition (literary technique)]] *[[Fiction writing]] *[[Literature]] *[[Writing]] *[[Discourse community]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * {{citation |last=Rozakis |first=Laurie E |title=Complete Idiot's Guide to Grammar and Style |publisher=Penguin |year=2003 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8dbDjgc7voIC&pg=PA271#v=onepage&q=%22modes%20of%20discourse%22&f=false |isbn=1-59257-115-8 |accessdate=24 September 2014 |page=271}} * {{cite journal |pages=444-455 |title=The Rise and Fall of the Modes of Discourse |last=Connors| year=1981 |first=Robert |journal=College Composition and Communication |publisher=Jstor |volume=32 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/356607}} *{{citation |title = The Marshall Plan for Novel Writing |first = E |last = Marshall |publisher = Writer's Digest Books |location = Cincinnati, OH |year = 1998 |pages = 143–165 |isbn = 1-58297-062-9 }} *{{citation |title = Between the Lines: Master the Subtle Elements of Fiction Writing |first = JP |last = Morrell |publisher = Writer's Digest Books |location = Cincinnati, OH |year = 2006 |pages = 127 |isbn = 978-1-58297-393-7 }} *{{citation |first = P |last = Selgin |title = By Cunning & Craft: Sound Advice and Practical Wisdom for fiction writers |publisher = Writer's Digest Books |location = Cincinnati, OH |year = 2007 |pages = 38 |isbn = 978-1-58297-491-0 }}
==External links== *[http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/685/02/ The Expository Essay] *[http://stanford.edu/~arnetha/expowrite/info.html#what What is Expository Writing?]

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2007}} '''Sust 'n' Able''' is the [[Woodcraft Folk]]'s programme of education for [[sustainable development]]. [[Image:sustnable.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Sust'N'Able Logo]]
The project was the theme of the Woodcraft Folk's 2001 international camp in [[Nottinghamshire]] where 4,000 young people attended. The camp focused on sustainable development education and ran activates for children from five to twenty five around the themes.
At the camp a simulation game took place called '''World on a Tight Rope'', it ran the length of the camp and involved people working for credits to create a more sustainable world. The simulation included two 'Earth Summits' held at the camp to come up with a declaration to the world's leaders at the [[World Summit on Sustainable Development]] (WSSD). The Earth Summit had "action stations" where people debated the issues to be included in the declaration.
==The declaration and delegation== The Declaration created as part of the simulation game was presented by a delegation of 11 young people. The delegation attended the [[United Nations]]' [[World Summit on Sustainable Development]] including both the civil society and the official political areas of the summit. The group worked with the [[International Falcon Movement - Socialist Education International]] delegation attending the summit.
Delegations from Woodcraft Folk attend all the [[Commission on Sustainable Development]] meetings in [[New York City]] which are follow-up meetings to the annual WSSD, with thematic cycles changing every two years.
==External links== *[http://www.woodcraft.org.uk Woodcraft Folk Official website] *[http://sustnable.woodcraft.org.uk Sust'n'Able - Woodcraft Folk Sustainabllity pages]

{{Infobox university | name = TESST College of Technology | image=TESST College of Technology Logo.jpeg | image_size=355px | established = 1957 | type = [[for-profit school|For-profit]] | head_label = President | head = Kevin Beaver | city = [[Baltimore]] | state = [[Maryland]] | country = [[United States|USA]] | website = [http://www.tesst.com TESST College of Technology ] | campus = [[Suburban]] }} '''TESST College of Technology''' is a private for-profit technical college located in metropolitan [[Baltimore, Maryland]]. It is owned and operated by Education Corporation of America.
==History== TESST College of Technology began offering instruction in electronics in 1957 as TESST Technology Institute. The campus was located in [[Hyattsville, Maryland]]. In December 1992, TESST expanded its reach in the Baltimore market by acquiring the Arundel Institute of Technology. In the summer of 1998, the Hyattsville and Baltimore campuses relocated to new buildings in [[Beltsville, Maryland|Beltsville]] and [[Towson, Maryland]].
In 1999, TESST acquired RETS Technical Training Center, which had been offering classes in Maryland since 1956. In June 2001, TESST Technology Institute received approval to offer associate of applied science degrees in network information systems and electronics, computer, and telecommunications technology.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} All campuses then became known as TESST College of Technology.
In May 2002, the College was acquired by Quest Education Corporation, a subsidiary of Kaplan, Inc.<ref name="History">{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-85932155.html|title=Acquisition by Kaplan, Inc.|publisher=PR Newswire|accessdate=2009-08-12}}</ref> In December 2002, Quest changed its name to Kaplan Higher Education Corporation. In March 2004, the campus expanded by adding a {{convert|6800|sqft|m2|adj=on}} facility located at 3922 Vero Road, less than a mile from the campus.
In September 2015, TESST College of Technology was acquired by [[Education Corporation of America]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Education Corporation of America Completes Purchase of Kaplan Campuses|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/education-corporation-of-america-completes-purchase-of-kaplan-college-campuses-300137913.html|publisher=PR Newswire|accessdate=3 September 2015}}</ref>
==Campuses== There are 3 campuses: Baltimore Campus (698 students),<ref name="Baltimore Campuse">{{cite web|url=http://nces.ed.gov/COLLEGENAVIGATOR/?q=TESST&s=all&id=163736|title=Baltimore Campus|publisher=U.S. Department of Education. Institute of Education Sciences|accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref> Beltsville Campus (413 students)<ref name="Beltsville Campus">{{cite web|url=http://nces.ed.gov/COLLEGENAVIGATOR/?q=TESST&s=all&id=164058|title=Beltsville Campus|publisher=U.S. Department of Education. Institute of Education Sciences|accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref> and Towson Campus (322 students).<ref name="Towson Campus">{{cite web|url=http://nces.ed.gov/COLLEGENAVIGATOR/?q=TESST&s=all&id=161776|title=Towson Campus|publisher=U.S. Department of Education. Institute of Education Sciences|accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
==Academics== TESST College of Technology offers programs in the following fields:<ref name="Academics">{{cite web|url=http://www.tesst.com/Pages/microportalhome.aspx|title=Programs|publisher=TESST College|accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref>
*Allied Health Medical Assistant (Certificate); Medical Billing and Coding Specialist (Certificate); Pharmacy Technician (Certificate) *Information Technology: Computer Support Technician (Certificate); Computer Networking Technology (Associate of Applied Science) *Trades: Electrician (Certificate); Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning/Refrigeration (Certificate) *Criminal Justice (Associate of Applied Science) *Continuing Education: Drywall Technician course, Phlebotomy Technician course and Security Plus test prep course
==References== {{reflist}}

Retrieved on 2009-08-12.] *[https://archive.is/20130203160317/http://baltimore.tesst.com/ TESST College of Technology - Baltimore] *[https://archive.is/20130203143413/http://beltsville.tesst.com/ TESST College of Technology - Beltsville] *[https://archive.is/20130203134359/http://towson.tesst.com/ TESST College of Technology - Towson]

'''Tagging of Pacific Predators''' ('''TOPP''') began in 2000 as one of many projects formed by [[Census of Marine Life]],<ref name="A TOPP">{{cite web|url=http://topp.org/about_topp |title=TOPP |publisher=TOPP |date= |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref><ref name="Census">{{cite web|url=http://www.thew2o.net/census |title=Census of Marine Life |publisher=Census of Marine Life |accessdate=2009-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131140753/http://thew2o.net/census |archivedate=January 31, 2009 }}</ref> an organization whose goal is to help understand and explain the diversity and abundances of the ocean in the past, present, and future.<ref name="Census" /> After they were formed, TOPP began by building a coalition of researchers from all over the world to find and study predators of the Pacific Ocean.<ref name="TOPP Youtube">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/TOPPpredators |title=Youtube, Tagging of Pacific Predators |publisher=Youtube |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref> Since then, they have satellite-tagged 22 different species and more than 2,000 animals.<ref name="P TOPP">{{cite web|url=http://www.polartrec.com/resources/web-link/3285 |title=TOPP |publisher=Polar Trec |accessdate=2009-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724115907/http://www.polartrec.com/resources/web-link/3285 |archivedate=July 24, 2011 }}</ref> These animals include [[elephant seals]], [[great white sharks]], [[leatherback turtles]], [[squid]], [[albatrosses]], and more.<ref name="zooillogix">{{cite web|url=http://scienceblogs.com/zooillogix/tagging_of_pacific_predators/ |title=Zooillogix |publisher=Zooillogix |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref><ref name="Scientists">{{cite web|url=http://news-service.stanford.edu/news/2007/march14/squid-031407.html?view=print |title=Scientists Conduct Tagging Study |publisher=Standard Report |date=2007-03-08 |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref>
Through the efforts of TOPP, information never before accessed by humans was now available, such as migration routes and ecosystems,<ref name="A TOPP" /><ref name="Tagging PP">{{cite web|url=http://news.mongabay.com/2008/0217-hance_sharks.html |title=Tagging of Pacific Pelagics, (TOPP) |publisher=SIMoN |date=200-11-20 |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref> but from the animals', rather than human, aspects.<ref name="M aquarium">{{cite web|url=http://www.montereybayaquarium.org/cr/topp.asp |title=Monterey Bay Aquarium |publisher=Montery Bay Aquarium |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref> It also became possible to learn about the ocean itself through use of the animals, because they can go where humans cannot. We learn through their everyday actions, and through these data, researchers have been able to determine better ways of protecting endangered species, such as the leatherback turtle.<ref name="A TOPP" /><ref name="T Ocean">{{cite web|url=http://www.seaturtles.org/article.php?id=1283 |title=Sea Turtle Restoration Project |publisher=Sea Turtle Restoration Project |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref><ref name="Endangered">{{cite web|url=http://www.xray-mag.com/en/node/658 |title=Satellite Tagging Research |publisher=X-Ray Magazine |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref>
==Organization== In addition to the [[National Marine Fisheries Service|NOAA’s Pacific Fisheries Ecosystems Lab]], Stanford’s [[Hopkins Marine Station#Hopkins Marine Station|Hopkins Marine Lab]], and [[University of California, Santa Cruz]]’s Long Marine Laboratory,<ref name="A TOPP" /><ref name="T Census">{{cite web|url=http://www.coml.org/projects/tagging-pacific-predators-topp |title=Census of Marine Life, TOPP |publisher=Census of Marine Life |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref> a wide range of people contribute to the success of the program, including [[marine biologist]]s, [[oceanographer]]s, engineers, computer programmers, journalists, graphic designers, educators and the public who provide support.<ref name="A TOPP" />
==Tagging== [[File:Elephant seal tag.jpg|thumb|right|A CDT tag taken off an elephant seal at Año Nuevo State Reserve]] Many different types of tags are used in the TOPP tagging program, each designed for different marine animals and different types of data.<ref name="KQED">{{cite web|url=http://www.kqed.org/quest/television/view/924 |title=KQED Quest Television Story |publisher=KQED |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref> Archival tags, though small, are very powerful, and can last up to 10 years.<ref name="A TOPP" /> Researchers surgically implant them into the bellies of tuna, where the tags record, as often as every few seconds, pressure (for depth of dives), ambient light (to estimate location), internal and external body temperature, and, in some cases, speed of travel.<ref name="A TOPP" /> The tags are small and light enough to be attached to the outside of an animal, such as the tail feathers of red-footed boobies. However, they do have a drawback, they have to be retrieved. So, they are useful for fish likely to be caught as seafood, such as bluefin or yellowfin tuna,<ref name="bluefin">{{cite web |url=http://tagagiant.org/Science.Pac.shtml |title=Tag-A-Giant Foundation |publisher=TAG |accessdate=2009-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219062345/http://tagagiant.org/Science.Pac.shtml |archivedate=2009-02-19 |df= }}</ref> or animals that return to rookeries or nesting beaches, such as boobies and leatherback turtles.<ref name="A TOPP" /><ref name="Youtube Turtle">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dxOfsySiS-s&feature=channel_page |title=Youtube, Tagging Leatherback Turtle |publisher=Youtube |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref>
[[Pop-up Satellite Archival Tag|Pop-up satellite archival tags]] (PSATs), also known simply as pop-up archival tags (PATs), are just like archival tags, except they are designed to release at a preset time, like 30 days. They then float to the surface and send their data via an Argos satellite back to the laboratory for two weeks, which is the life of its battery.<ref name="A TOPP" /> Even when the battery dies, the data are saved on the tag, so if it is ever recovered, the whole data set can be downloaded. This tag is useful for animals that do not spend a lot of time at the surface, and are not caught often.<ref name="A TOPP" /> Numerous white sharks have been tagged with this tag.<ref name="Mysterious Shark">{{cite web|url=http://news.mongabay.com/2008/0217-hance_sharks.html |title=Mysteries of the Great White Shark |publisher=Mongabay.com |date=2008-02-17 |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref><ref name="Underwater shark">{{cite web|url=http://www.underwatertimes.com/news.php?article_id=71510839062 |title=Released Aquarium Great White Shark |publisher=Underwater Times |date=2008-05-20 |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref><ref name="Sign On San Diego">{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/state/20071118-9999-lz1n18shark.html |title=Tracking the White Shark |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2007-11-18 |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref><ref name="Youtube Shark">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sOb0ywsbKA8&feature=channel_page |title=Youtube, Tagged White Shark |publisher=Youtube |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref> The tags are attached to white sharks by inserting a small surgical titanium anchor into it.<ref name="Blue Sharks">{{cite web|url=http://www.pac.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/sci/sa-mfpd/elasmobranchs/blueshark_tagging.htm |title=Blue Shark Tagging |publisher=Groundfish |accessdate=2009-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805181024/http://www.pac.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/sci/sa-mfpd/elasmobranchs/blueshark_tagging.htm |archivedate=August 5, 2009 }}</ref> On elephant seals, the tag is glued to the fur.<ref name="Youtube Elephant Seal">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kh-1JkScKEQ&feature=channel_page |title=Youtube, Tagging Elephant Seals |publisher=Youtube |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref> Connecting the tag to the anchor is a thin line that loops around a metal pin at the base of the tag.<ref name="A TOPP" /> This metal pin is connected to a battery. A clock in the tag turns the battery on at a preprogrammed time. When the battery turns on, the attachment pin dissolves. The tag floats to the surface and starts transmitting data to one of the Argos satellites.<ref name="A TOPP" />
Spot tags, or smart positioning, or temperature transmitting tags, are ideal tags for air-breathing marine animals (seals, whales and sea turtles) and animals that often swim close to the surface (salmon sharks, blue sharks and makos).<ref name="A TOPP" /> When the antenna breaks the surface, it sends data to a satellite. The data include pressure, speed, and water temperature. Location is estimated by calculating the Doppler shift in the transmission signal in successive transmissions.<ref name="A TOPP" /> When the animal goes beneath the surface, a saltwater switch turns off the tag. The tag, made by Wildlife Computers, lasts about two years.<ref name="Wildlife">{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifecomputers.com/ |title=Wildlife Computers |publisher=Wildlife Computers |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref>
Satellite relay data logger (SRDL) tags compress data so more information can be transmitted through the Argos satellite.<ref name="A TOPP" /> These can be outfitted with CTD tags to record the salinity, temperature and depth data oceanographers need to identify ocean currents and water.<ref name="A TOPP" /> Elephant seals, sea lions and leatherback sea turtles wear these tags.
==Programs== [[File:Ellie seal TOPP.jpg|thumb|An elephant seal named Ellie tagged though TOPP]] TOPP has also set up programs to engage the public in learning about marine science and marine conservation. One of its programs is called Elephant Seal Homecoming Days, which was started by TOPP in 2008 for the months the northern elephant seals return to Año Nuevo State Reserve during the breeding season. TOPP picks around 10 of the many they tagged to become "spokes-seals" for the public, allowing them to see what it is like being one of the biggest seals in the world.<ref name="TOPP">{{cite web|url=http://topp.org/ |title=TOPP |publisher=TOPP |date= |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> Elephant seals are prime candidates for tagging because they tend to return to the same beach every year to breed, yielding high tag recovery.<ref name="Tagging of E Seals">{{cite web|url=http://www.elephantseal.org/E-Seals/tagging.htm |title=Tagging of Elephant Seals |publisher=Friends of the Elephant Seal |accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref> They can gather immense amounts of information because they can swim for thousands of miles.<ref name="NOAA">{{cite web|url=http://las.pfeg.noaa.gov/TOPP/ |title=NOAA |publisher=TOPP |accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref><ref name="UC News">{{cite web |url=http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/article/7889 |title=UC Newsroom |publisher=University of California |date=2006-02-21 |accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref> The seals are issued their own [[Facebook]] profile that is kept up for them by undergraduate volunteer keepers.<ref name="facebook">{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/people/Penelope-Seal/792464921 |title=Penelope Seal's Facebook |publisher=Facebook |accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref> Facebook profiles keep the public updated on their progress while they give birth and proceed to take care of their pups. Two seals are the stars of TOPP Elephant Seal Homecoming Days. The first is Penelope Seal, who has been part of the program since 2008. The second one is new as of 2009, and his name is Stelephant Colbert (in reference to [[Stephen Colbert]] of ''[[The Colbert Report]]'').<ref name="Stelephant">{{cite web|url=http://www.nofactzone.net/?p=10657 |title=Stelephant Colbert |publisher=No Fact Zone |date=2009-01-29 |accessdate=2009-02-21}}</ref>
*Early years Stelephant started out as a mere pup in a small harem of northern elephant seals located at Año Nuevo State Reserve.<ref name="Ano Nuevo">{{cite web|url=http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=523 |title=Año Nuevo State Reserve |publisher=CA.gov |accessdate=2009-09-26}}</ref> He has since grown into one of the most famous elephant seals ever, even appearing on ''The Colbert Report''. Around eight years old, Stelephant is a 4,500-pound beast. Not known as the pretty-boy, he gets by on his aggressiveness and determination to get as close to females as possible. With his proboscis, or nose, high in the air, almost any male is turned away unless they wish to fight.<ref name="Fighting males">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ct_Bq3KpVmQ |title=Back To The Fight"Males at Año Nuevo |publisher=Youtube |date=2008-01-28}}</ref> These fights are not known to last for long, however, because Stelephant is a seasoned fighter and knows how to win. He is what every male elephant seal strives to be, huge, strong, and proud.
When Stelephant Colbert was weaned, he spent the next few weeks on the beach waiting for the courage to go and join the adult seals out in the northern Pacific Ocean. He returned the next year to the same beach on the California coast as a yearling, where he was exiled to the outskirts of the harems with all the other yearlings. The next few years were spent building muscle and growing large to be able to compete with the larger males. During his third to fifth year, Stelephant practiced his fighting skills with other young males to build strength; while he did compete with the adults, he was not much competition and spent most of his days far away from females.<ref name="marine mammals">{{cite web|url=http://www.marinemammalcenter.org/learning/education/pinnipeds/noelephseal.asp |title=Elephant Seals |publisher =The Marine Mammal Center |accessdate=2009-03-04}}</ref> When he was around seven years old with his proboscis finally grown in, he was finally ready to compete with the adult males for the alpha position.
*Tagging Stelephant has been involved with the University of California, Santa Cruz Long Marine Lab researchers, and was tagged last spring to track his foraging habits while swimming and diving off the [[Aleutian Islands]] in the northern Pacific Ocean.
*Current Stelephant was issued his own Facebook page, where people can keep track of his whereabouts and his status updates.<ref name="Meet">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailybreeze.com/news/ci_11601414 |date=2009-01-31 |accessdate=2009-02-26 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> He is the most talked-about seal in the program in that he was featured in the Santa Cruz Stelephant is now an alpha male at Año Nuevo State Reserve, and will soon return to the ocean to forage once again. Stelephant was featured on Oceans Google Earth, which allows the user to explore the oceans.<ref name="oceans">{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/centralcoast/ci_11614425?nclick_check=1 |title=Google Ocean allows underwater exploration without the wetsuit |date=2009-02-03 |accessdate= 2009-03-03}}</ref><ref name="SC Oceans">{{cite web|url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/localnews/ci_11614425?source=rss |title= Google Ocean allows underwater exploration without the wetsuit |publisher=Santa Cruz Sentinel |date=2009-02-03 |accessdate=2009-03-03}}</ref> His tags were recovered in January and he was not tagged again.
==Penelope Seal== Penelope Seal is an elephant seal and one of the many marine animals tagged as a part of the TOPP program.
Penelope was born as a "little" {{Convert|90|lb|kg|abbr=on}} pup in early January 1998 at the [[Año Nuevo State Reserve]] on the [[California]]n coast.<ref name="ianimals">{{cite web |url=http://www.ianimals.com/videoplay/Pups_and_mom_elephant_seals_at_A%C3%B1o_Nuevo_State_Reserve.html |title=iAnimals |publisher=iAnimals |accessdate=2003-03-03}}</ref> Since then, she has become a {{Convert|1500|lb|kg|abbr=on}} full grown female northern elephant seal with six pups of her own, and many fans who have contributed to her fame.<ref name="The Marine Mammal Center">{{cite web |url=http://www.marinemammalcenter.org/learning/education/pinnipeds/noelephseal.asp |title=The Marine Mammal Center |publisher=The Marine Mammal Center |date= |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> From five years old, she has had one pup a year, all at Año Nuevo State Reserve. Penelope Seal is known as gnarly seal and a survivor, considering 50% of her species will die before they reach maturity.<ref name="TOPP elephant seals">{{cite web |url=http://www.topp.org/species/elephant_seals |title=Elephant Seals |publisher=TOPP |date= |accessdate=2009-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215031553/http://topp.org/species/elephant_seals |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}</ref> She has beautiful dark-brown fur that she molts (or sheds) once a year. The beach is a known hangout spot of hers and one can usually spot her basking in the sun, or if its raining, cuddling up to another elephant seal. She has had multiple relationships, never known to be a [[monogamous]] seal, and in fact living in a [[polygynous]] society. The group, or harem, is made up of many other females and an alpha male with which Penelope has been known to hang out.<ref name="The Marine Mammal Center" /> However, Penelope has also been seen socializing with some other beta males around the harem, much to the dismay of the alpha. *Early life Penelope spent her early life as a weaner, or weaned pup, at Año Nuevo State Reserve. During this time she fasted on the beach waiting until she was brave enough to go out into the open ocean for the first time. The next year she became a yearling and spent her days being shunned from her harem, since she was still small compared to the others. Years two and three were spent much the same way. During this period she learned a lot about how to become a successful predator, like being able to travel all the way out into the northern Pacific Ocean and back again without any maps, and making it to the same place every time, which can be around an {{Convert|8000|mi|km|abbr=on}} journey. However, when she was four years old, she became pregnant with her first pup and gave birth to him 10 months later at Año Nuevo State Reserve. *Tagging Penelope is tagged with a small tag and collects data for the TOPP team's researchers. Penelope's tag has a time depth recorder,<ref>http://www.lotek.com/archival.htm</ref> which documents the dive depth, dive duration, and light levels.<ref name="E Seal">{{cite web|url=http://topp.org/species/elephant_seals |title=Elephant Seals |publisher=TOPP |date= |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> Elephant seals are incredible divers and allow scientists to learn about their unique behavior and the environment in which they live. Elephant seals are prime candidates for tagging because they tend to return to the same beach every year to breed, yielding high tag recovery.<ref name="Tagging of E Seals"/> They can gather immense amounts of information because they can swim for thousands of miles.<ref name="NOAA"/><ref name="UC News"/> Penelope herself has been involved with the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]] Long Marine Lab researchers and was tagged last year.
*Current Penelope has since had her seventh pup, and is living on the beaches of Año Nuevo State Reserve. She was not tagged this year. Stelephant Colbert has since taken on the challenge of promoting elephant seals, and has been quite successful.<ref name="colbertnation">{{cite web |url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/217977/february-05-2009/stelephant-colbert-the-elephant-seal |title=Stelephant Colbert The Elephant Seal |publisher=The Colbert Report |date=2009-02-05 |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref>
Penelope is featured on the new version of Ocean [[Google Earth]], which allows the user to explore the oceans. Penelope can be located at Año Nuevo State Reserve.<ref name="Oceans">{{cite web| url=http://www.justmagic.com/GM-GE.html |title=Google Ocean |publisher=Magic Instinct Software |accessdate=2009-09-17}}</ref><ref name="Blog">{{cite web |url=http://www.topp.org/blog/penelope_returns |title=Penelope Returns! |publisher=TOPP |date=2009-02-06 |accessdate=2009-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211142441/http://topp.org/blog/penelope_returns |archivedate=2009-02-11 |df= }}</ref><ref name="meet pen">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hxrhwj_SPOw |title=Meet Penelope Seal On Google Ocean! |publisher=Google Earth |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref><ref name="The Oceans">{{cite web|url=http://www.underwatertimes.com/news.php?article_id=01029837156 |title=Underwater Times |publisher=UnderwaterTimes.com |date=2009-02-02 |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref>
Penelope Seal has been the star of Elephant Seal Homecoming Days for the past two years. She enabled TOPP to engage the public in learning about northern elephant seals, marine science, and marine conservation.
==The Great Turtle Race== The Great Turtle Race is an international sea turtle conservation event that brings together corporate sponsors and conservation organizations. The race tracks sea turtles as they move toward feeding areas south of the Galapagos Islands after nesting at Playa Grande in Costa Rica’s Las Baulas National Park, the primary nesting area for leatherbacks in the Pacific.
TOPP is a cosponsor of The Great Turtle Race, and tracking technology created and used by TOPP is how the turtles are tracked. The race occurred in 2007 and 2008 in April.<ref>http://www.wildlifeextra.com/go/news/leatherback-race.html#cr</ref>

{{good article}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Italic title}} [[File:Page from The Indian Antiquary.jpg|thumbnail|right|Cover page of a 1931 edition of ''The Indian Antiquary'']] '''''The Indian Antiquary, A journal of oriental research in archaeology, history, literature, language, philosophy, religion, folklore, &c, &c,''''' (subtitle varies) was a journal of original research relating to India, published between 1872 and 1933. It was founded by the archaeologist [[James Burgess (archaeologist)|James Burgess]] to enable the sharing of knowledge between scholars based in Europe and in India and was notable for the high quality of its epigraphic illustrations which enabled scholars to make accurate translations of texts that in many cases remain the definitive versions to this day. It was also pioneering in its recording of Indian [[folklore]]. It was succeeded by ''The New Indian Antiquary'' (1938-47) and the ''Indian Antiquary'' (1964-71).
==History== ''The Indian Antiquary'' was founded in 1872 by the archaeologist [[James Burgess (archaeologist)|James Burgess]] [[Order of the Indian Empire|CIE]] as a journal of original research relating to India. It was designed to enable the sharing of knowledge between scholars based in Europe and in India.<ref name=Pros>[http://indianhistorybooks.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/indian-antiquary-vol-i-1872.pdf Prospectus] in ''The Indian Antiquary'', Part 1, 5 January 1872, p. 1.</ref><ref>"The Indian Antiquary" in ''[[The Antiquaries Journal]]'', Vol. 2, No. 2, April 1922, p. 148.</ref>
The journal was a private venture,<ref name=Temp>[[Richard Carnac Temple|Temple, Richard Carnac]]. (1922) ''[https://archive.org/details/fiftyyearsofthei00temprich Fifty years of The Indian Antiquary]''. Mazgaon, Bombay: B. Miller, British India Press, pp. 3-4.</ref> although no contributor or editor was ever paid for their work and the editors often had to support the publication out of their own pockets.<ref name=Temp/> Burgess was the first editor and he continued in that role until the end of 1884 when failing eyesight forced him to hand over to John Faithfull Fleet and [[Richard Carnac Temple]].<ref name=Temp/>
The late nineteenth century was marked by a great increase in the number of local historical societies in India and a similar increase in the number of Indians who could speak and write English, to the extent that by the 1920s the entire journal could have been filled with work by Indian contributors.<ref name="Temple, p. 7"/> Volumes for 1925 to 1932 were published under the authority of the Council of the [[Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland|Royal Anthropological Institute]] (1933, not).<ref name=sun/> The first incarnation of the ''Antiquary'' ceased publication in 1933 with volume 62, number 783 (Dec. 1933),<ref name=sun>[http://suncat.ac.uk/serials/SC00623823801/all ''Indian antiquary''.] Suncat. Retrieved 10 January 2017.</ref> two years after Richard Temple's death in 1931.<ref name="odnb">{{cite web |title=Temple, Sir Richard Carnac, second baronet (1850–1931), army officer and oriental scholar |first=R. E. |last=Enthoven |authorlink=Reginald Edward Enthoven |others=Revised by Jones, M. G. M. |work=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography |publisher=Oxford University Press |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36453 |accessdate=10 January 2017}} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> Several early volumes of the journal were reprinted by Swati Publications in Delhi, 1984.<ref>[https://openlibrary.org/books/OL25104914M/The_Indian_Antiquary ''The Indian Antiquary''.] Open Library. Retrieved 9 January 2017.</ref>
The '''''New Indian Antiquary''''' was published between 1938<ref>[http://www.southasiaarchive.com/Content/sarf.120202 ''New Indian Antiquary''.] South Asia Archive, 2014. Retrieved 30 May 2014.</ref> and 1947, and the '''''Indian Antiquary''''' (described as the "third series") between 1964 and 1971.<ref name=BL>''Indian Antiquary'', British Library catalogue search, 29 May 2014.</ref> (Volumes 14 to 62 of the original ''Antiquary'' were described as the "second series".)<ref>''Indian Antiquary'', British Library catalogue search, 10 January 2017.</ref>
==Content== The journal had an archaeological and historical focus, and in the late nineteenth century that naturally meant that [[epigraphy]] (the study of inscriptions as writing rather than as literature) would be one of the principal subjects covered in its pages.<ref name=Sal>{{cite book|author=Salomon, Richard (1998)|title=Indian Epigraphy: A Guide to the Study of Inscriptions in Sanskrit, Prakrit, and the other Indo-Aryan Languages: A Guide to the Study of Inscriptions in Sanskrit, Prakrit, and the other Indo-Aryan Languages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XYrG07qQDxkC&pg=PA219|date=|location= New York|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=978-0-19-535666-3|page=219}}</ref> Indeed, the ''Antiquary'' was the premier source of European scholarship on Indian epigraphy until the twentieth century and the official Indian government journal of epigraphy, the ''[[Epigraphia Indica]]'', was published as a quarterly supplement to the ''Antiquary'' between 1892 and 1920.<ref name=Temp/>
The ''Antiquary'' was printed at [[Mazgaon]], Bombay, by the [[Bombay Education Society]] and later the British India Press, but illustrations were produced in London by the firm of Griggs who were known for the accuracy of their work.<ref name=Temple.p.6/> A high standard of reproduction was essential so that scholars could work on the epigraphic material without needing to see the originals.<ref name=Temple.p.6>Temple, p. 6.</ref> Illustrations in the ''Antiquary'' were used by scholars such as Bhandarkar, [[Bhagvanlal Indraji]], [[Georg Bühler]], [[John Faithfull Fleet]], Eggeling and B. Lewis Rice to decipher important inscriptions,<ref>[http://asi.nic.in/asi_aboutus_history.asp ''History'',] [[Archaeological Survey of India]], 2011. Retrieved 30 May 2014.</ref> and in many cases their translations remain the definitive versions to this day.<ref name=Sal/>
Over one thousand plates were included in ''The Indian Antiquary'' and the ''Epigraphia Indica'' over the first fifty years of publication, but having the illustrations produced abroad was not without its disadvantages. On one occasion during World War I, enemy action meant that expensive plates had to be sent from London three times before they reached Bombay safely.<ref name=Temple.p.6/>
Another area where the ''Antiquary'' led was in recording folklore and folktales. Its publication of [[Punjab region|Punjab]] folktales was the first attempt to classify the events on which folk tales were based<ref name="Temple, p. 7">[https://archive.org/stream/fiftyyearsofthei00temprich#page/6/mode/2up Temple, p. 7.]</ref> and the pioneering work on north Indian folklore of [[William Crooke]] and [[Ram Gharib Chaube|Pandit Ram Gharib Chaube]] was printed in its pages.<ref name="CrookeChaube2002">"Introduction" by Sadhana Naithani in {{cite book|author1=William Crooke|author2=Pandit Ram Gharib Chaube|author3=|title=Folktales from Northern India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RcK2l0yE1OsC&pg=PT38|date=2002|location=Santa Barbara|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-698-9|page=38}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{commons category|The Indian Antiquary|''The Indian Antiquary''}} * [https://archive.org/search.php?query=The%20Indian%20antiquary ''The Indian Antiquary'' at archive.org]

{{infobox writer | name = Thomas Forsthoefel | image = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | alma_mater = | spouse = [[Beth Gylys]] | occupation = Professor, Author, Poet | subject = '''Non-fiction:'''
Religious studies
'''Poetry:'''
death, loss, healing, redemption | awards = Poet Laureate for
Erie County, PA, 2010-11 | nationality = American }} '''Thomas Forsthoefel''' is a professor of [[religious studies]] at [[Mercyhurst University]] in [[Erie, Pennsylvania]], as well as a [[poet]] and [[author]].[http://dalailamafilm.com/cast-thomas-forsthoefel/thomas-forsthoefel-biography-soulsong-dalai-lama-essential-writings-gurus-in-america.html Biography], Dalai Lama film He has a special interest in [[Hinduism]] and [[Buddhism]] and has written on both [[new religious movements]] and established traditions within these faiths, while his own background is [[Roman Catholic]].{{cite news|last=Massing|first=Dana|title=Essential Writings|url=http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081129/LIFESTYLES03/311299978/-1/LIFESTYLES|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=Erie Times-News|date=29 November 2008}} He is married to [[Beth Gylys]], professor of English and Creative Writing at [[Georgia State University]] and a fellow poet.{{cite web|url=http://merciad.mercyhurst.edu/content/singers-perform-poetry-matchbook|title=Singers perform poetry in 'Matchbook'|work=Merciad}} ==Biography== In 1999, Forsthoefel met the [[14th Dalai Lama]] while attending a conference of scholars in [[India]]. In 2008 he edited an anthology of the Dalai Lama's writings and contributed to a documentary film on him. In 2010, Forsthoefel was named [[Poet Laureate]] of [[Erie County, Pennsylvania]].{{cite news|last=Poisson|first=Lindsey|title=Mercyhurst College professor Tom Forsthoefel becomes Erie County's new poet laureate|url=http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100914/NEWS02/309139924/-1/rss|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=Erie Times-News|date=14 September 2010}} He said that he was going to use that position to promote a program to introduce poetry to people incarcerated in local prisons.[http://www.mercyhurst.edu/news/news-releases/article/?article_id=2271 Forsthoefel named Poet Laureate], Mercyhurst College His tenure as poet laureate was renewed for 2011.{{cite news|last=Boyd|first=Brandon|title=Erie County poet laureate gets second year in post|url=http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110622/NEWS02/306229955/-1/RSS01|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=Erie Times-News|date=22 June 2011}} In 2011, ''[[The New York Times]]'' quoted Forsthoefel concerning the high school from which he had graduated, [[Fordson High School]] of [[Detroit]], and its overnight football practices to accommodate Muslim students fasting for [[Ramadan]]: {{quote|I think it is really in keeping with the best instincts of Islam in honoring the Ramadan fast, which, in my view, is an intentional disruption of quotidian life in order to affirm and galvanize key principles of Islam and to live under submission to Allah. I find that very honorable and a real testimony to the awareness that there is something going on in life other than making a buck or seeing the bottom line.|Thomas Forsthoefel|''The New York Times''{{cite news|last=Longman|first=Jeré|title=All-Nighters for a Football Team During Ramadan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/11/sports/football/all-nighters-keep-football-team-competitive-during-ramadan.html?_r=1|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=10 August 2011}}}} ==Published works== Forsthoefel's published books include:[http://www.google.com/search?tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=thomas+forsthoefel&num=10 Google Books] *''Four charismatic thinkers on violence and non-violence: analysis and evaluation'' ([[Loyola University of Chicago]], 1987) *''Epistemologies of religious experience in medieval and modern Vedānta'' ([[University of Chicago Divinity School]]), 1998) *''Knowing beyond knowledge: epistemologies of religious experience in classical and modern Advaita'' ([[Ashgate Publishing|Ashgate]], 2002) *''Gurus in America'' co-editor with [[Cynthia Ann Humes]] ([[SUNY Press]], 2005) *''Soulsong: Seeking Holiness, Coming Home'' ([[Orbis Books]], 2006) *''The Dalai Lama: essential writings'' editor ([[Orbis Books]], 2008) ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Forsthoefel, Thomas}} [[Category:American male poets]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Religious studies scholars]] [[Category:Researchers of new religious movements and cults]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]]
